instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-2532: What is 820-2532? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PP5V_S0: What is PP5V_S0? PP5V_S0 is a 5v power rail present when the system is in an S0 working state..
definitions.PP3V3_S0: What is PP3V3_S0? The "PP3V3_S0" rail in a MacBook logic board is a power rail that supplies 3.3 volts to the system when it is fully awake (S0 state). .
definitions.C7771: What is C7771? Tantalum capacitor on 820-2330 and 820-2532 logic boards that often dies and causes PP1V05_S5_MCP or PP1V05_S5 to be 0.331v instead of 1.05v. If heating this cap restores voltage to this rail, replace.

threads.title: [SOLVED] <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2532</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no <SIGNAL>PP5V_S0</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
Hey guys, this one is really throwing me for a loop --

Came in with history of customer ultrasonically cleaning it, also with the note of "Magsafe sparked when plugged in" 

Went through the rails -- 

All rails present except <SIGNAL>PP5V_S0</SIGNAL>

<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S0</SIGNAL> is present. 

<CHIP>U7500</CHIP> and <TRANSISTOR>Q7511</TRANSISTOR>/10 had some residue and <CHIP>U7500</CHIP> and a red probe point (<SIGNAL>PP5V_S0_MCPREG_VCC</SIGNAL>) . Replaced <CHIP>U7500</CHIP> and <TRANSISTOR>Q7511</TRANSISTOR>. Still nothing. 

Pp5V <SIGNAL>RT_S0_BOOT</SIGNAL> present 

<SIGNAL>PP5V_RT_LGATE</SIGNAL> missing

<SIGNAL>PP5V_RT_PHASE</SIGNAL> missing

<SIGNAL>PP5V_RT_S0_UGATE</SIGNAL> missing

EN, VCC, and VIN  present to <CHIP>U7500</CHIP>

This is not a <CAPACITOR>C7771</CAPACITOR> issue as well.

If I supply 5v to 5v S0 vcore is present and drops to .99 indicating post.

threads.title: [SOLVED] <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2532</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no <SIGNAL>PP5V_S0</SIGNAL>
threads.message: <SIGNAL>P5V_RTS0_EN</SIGNAL> present? Why not replaced <TRANSISTOR>Q7510</TRANSISTOR>? Check all traces around <CHIP>U7500</CHIP>?

threads.title: [SOLVED] <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2532</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no <SIGNAL>PP5V_S0</SIGNAL>
threads.message: <SIGNAL>P5V_RTS0_EN</SIGNAL> is present. <TRANSISTOR>Q7510</TRANSISTOR> and 11 were both replaced at the same time as <CHIP>U7500</CHIP>. Don't see a issue with any of the traces around <CHIP>U7500</CHIP> and I checked the signals from <CHIP>U7500</CHIP> to the fets. All have continuity from the pins on the chip to the fets

threads.title: [SOLVED] <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2532</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no <SIGNAL>PP5V_S0</SIGNAL>
threads.message: There is not much to this. It is either another bad <CHIP>ISL6236</CHIP> or corroded trace, <CAPACITOR>C7514</CAPACITOR> possibly. Take off the ISL and double check all traces for the 5V side of this circuit.

threads.title: [SOLVED] <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2532</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no <SIGNAL>PP5V_S0</SIGNAL>
threads.message: Fixed. Customer removed <CAPACITOR>C7514</CAPACITOR> before it got here and I didn't notice. Thanks Duke
